initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

 == Migration to USA and Canada ==
 In 60-s, 70-s and 80-s years of the last century some part of the baptists (as well as other protestants groups of Ukraine) emigrated to USA and Canada. After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]]<ref>[http://www.slavicbaptist.org/alladdress_en.html ADDRESSES OF SLAVIC CHURCHES IN SACRAMENTO CALIFORNIA]</ref><ref>http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/419913.shtml Ukraine Weekly News]</ref>, [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref>.
 
+Many baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.
+
 == Korean Baptists ==
 Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]]<ref>[http://www.slavicbaptist.org/alladdress_en.html ADDRESSES OF SLAVIC CHURCHES IN SACRAMENTO CALIFORNIA]</ref><ref>http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/419913.shtml Ukraine Weekly News]</ref>, [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref>.
 
 Many baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.

In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

-Many baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.

In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==

* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==

* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

 == Korean Baptists ==

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The change appears to be informative and does not promote a divisive or hostile narrative.

Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
+During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the 1996 [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.  == Migration to USA and Canada ==
 In 1960s, '70s and '80s, some Baptists (as well as other Protestants groups of Ukraine) emigrated to USA and Canada. After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]]<ref>[http://www.slavicbaptist.org/alladdress_en.html ADDRESSES OF SLAVIC CHURCHES IN SACRAMENTO CALIFORNIA]</ref><ref>http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/419913.shtml Ukraine Weekly News]</ref>, [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref>.
@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@
 Many Baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Baptist denominations]]
[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

Not Weaponised. The changes made are administrative in nature, focusing on link maintenance rather than altering the narrative or introducing weaponised language.

After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]], [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid"/>.

 The Baptist Church in Ukraine has attracted many young people, and there are now over 20,000 young people enrolled in Baptist Universities. Many of these youths are taking part in evangelism and ministry.  A spokesperson for the Southern Baptist International Mission Board has said that "[in Ukraine] the new generation is what God will have to use to evangelize, disciple and train leaders."<ref>[http://www.bpnews.net/BPnews.asp?ID=26552 ''Ukrainian youth step toward change ''] Baptist Press.  Retrieved 10-31-07</ref>

 == Persecution ==
-During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the 1996 [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested. The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kiev and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
+During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the 1996 [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kiev and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
 
 == Migration to USA and Canada ==
-In 1960s, '70s and '80s, some Baptists (as well as other Protestants groups of Ukraine) emigrated to USA and Canada. After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]], [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid"/>.
+In 1960s, '70s and '80s, some Baptists (as well as other Protestants groups of Ukraine) emigrated to USA and Canada. After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian baptist communities in [[Sacramento]],{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} [[Philadelphia]]<ref name="maid">[http://eng.maidanua.org/node/747 Maidan News]</ref> and [[Pennsylvania]]<ref name="maid"/>.
 
-Many Baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.
+Many Baptist churches in Ukraine have sister churches in the United States or Canada, with whom they cooperate with in doing ministry and evangelism.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
 
 == Korean Baptists ==
 Beginning in 1993, the [[Koreans|Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Koreans|Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==

* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

{{reflist}}

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>
