Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

 The Evangelical Baptists also publish a magazine called ''The Evangelical Field''{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} and the newspaper ''Resurrection''.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} There is also a newspaper for the deaf and mute, entitled ''Voice in the Wilderness''.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Baptist denominations]]
[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

 [[Category:Baptist denominations in Europe]]
 [[Category:History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
 [[Category:Protestantism in Ukraine]]
+[[Category:Ukrainian Baptists]]

 In the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, some Baptists (as well as other Protestant groups from Ukraine) emigrated to the United States and Canada. After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian Baptist communities in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} and [[Philadelphia]].<ref name="maid">''All Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Fellowship Leaders meet with Ukrainian World Congress President, Maidan News, July 2007''</ref>

Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

 The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in 1864 on the river [[Inhul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kropyvnytskyi]] region), in a [[History of Germans in Russia, Ukraine and the Soviet Union|German settlement]]. The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

+The predecessors of today's Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], came to Ukraine in the 16th century, seeking refuge from their persecution by state churches in Germany and other European states.<ref name=risu/> They sought to spread their faith to the native [[Ukrainians#Ethnonym|Ruthenian/Ukrainian]] population, so Slavs were invited to Anabaptist prayer meetings and Bible studies.
 
 The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in 1864 on the river [[Inhul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kropyvnytskyi]] region), in a [[History of Germans in Russia, Ukraine and the Soviet Union|German settlement]]. In 1867, the first Ukrainian-speaking Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in 1907, and in 1908 the First All-[[Russian Empire|Russian]] Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipro]]).{{when|date=December 2010}} At the end of the 19th century, estimates are that there were from 100,000 to 300,000 Baptists in Ukraine.<ref>[http://ecbua.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=44&Itemid=29 History of the AUC ECB]  Всеукраїнський Союз Церков Євангельських Християн-Баптистів web site {{uk icon}}</ref>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

After the collapse of the USSR, migration and interaction with Western churches increased. At present, there are large Ukrainian Baptist communities in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} and [[Philadelphia]].<ref name="maid">''All Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Fellowship Leaders meet with Ukrainian World Congress President, Maidan News, July 2007''</ref>

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]

* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

{{reflist}}

(Winter, 2004), pp. 732-755.</ref> Prior to independence in 1991, [[Ukraine]] was home to the second largest Baptist community in the world, after the United States, and was called the “[[Bible Belt]]” of the Soviet Union.<ref name="NCEEER">{{cite journal | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2006_819_19g_Wanner.pdf | title=EVANGELICALISM AND THE RESURGENCE OF  RELIGION IN UKRAINE | author=Wanne, Catherine | journal=The National Council for Eurasian and East European Research | year=2006}}</ref> And today Ukrainian Baptists continue to be the largest protestant denomination in Ukraine and the second largest Baptist union in the world by the number of churches.
+The '''Baptist Church in Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Баптизм в Україні}}) is one of the oldest and most widespread<ref name=risu>{{Cite web |url=http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-10-14 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20050420001102/http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ |archive-date=2005-04-20 |url-status=dead }}</ref> [[Protestantism|Protestant Christian]] denominations in the country.  Before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], over half the 1.5 million acknowledged [[Baptists]] and Pentecostals in the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] lived in [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Ukraine]].<ref>Catherine Wanner.  ''Missionaries of Faith and Culture: Evangelical Encounters in Ukraine''.  Slavic Review, Vol. 63, No. 4. (Winter, 2004), pp. 732-755.</ref> Prior to independence in 1991, [[Ukraine]] was home to the second largest Baptist community in the world, after the United States, and was called the “[[Bible Belt]]” of the Soviet Union.<ref name="NCEEER">{{cite journal | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2006_819_19g_Wanner.pdf | title=EVANGELICALISM AND THE RESURGENCE OF  RELIGION IN UKRAINE | author=Wanne, Catherine | journal=The National Council for Eurasian and East European Research | year=2006}}</ref> And today Ukrainian Baptists continue to be among the largest protestant denominations in Ukraine and the second largest Baptist union in the world by the number of churches.
 
 ==History==
 The predecessors of today's Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], came to Ukraine in the 16th century, seeking refuge from their persecution by state churches in Germany and other European states.<ref name=risu/> They sought to spread their faith to the native [[Ukrainians#Ethnonym|Ruthenian/Ukrainian]] population, so Slavs were invited to Anabaptist prayer meetings and Bible studies.

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==

* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

{{reflist}}

+The '''Baptist Church in Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Баптизм в Україні}}) is one of the oldest and most widespread<ref name=risu>{{Cite web |url=http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-10-14 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20050420001102/http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ |archive-date=2005-04-20 |url-status=dead }}</ref> [[Protestantism|Protestant Christian]] denominations in the country.  Before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], over half the 1.5 million acknowledged [[Baptists]] and Pentecostals in the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] lived in [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Ukraine]].<ref>Catherine Wanner.  ''Missionaries of Faith and Culture: Evangelical Encounters in Ukraine''.  Slavic Review, Vol. 63, No. 4. (Winter, 2004), pp. 732-755.</ref> Prior to independence in 1991, [[Ukraine]] was home to the second largest Baptist community in the world, after the United States, and was called the “[[Bible Belt]]” of the Soviet Union.<ref name="NCEEER">{{cite journal | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2006_819_19g_Wanner.pdf | title=EVANGELICALISM AND THE RESURGENCE OF  RELIGION IN UKRAINE | author=Wanne, Catherine | journal=The National Council for Eurasian and East European Research | year=2006}}</ref> And today Ukrainian Baptists continue to be the largest protestant denomination in Ukraine and the second largest Baptist union in the world by the number of churches.
 
 ==History==
 The predecessors of today's Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], came to Ukraine in the 16th century, seeking refuge from their persecution by state churches in Germany and other European states.<ref name=risu/> They sought to spread their faith to the native [[Ukrainians#Ethnonym|Ruthenian/Ukrainian]] population, so Slavs were invited to Anabaptist prayer meetings and Bible studies.

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]

 ===Migration to North America===
 In the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, some Baptists (as well as other Protestant groups from Ukraine) emigrated to the United States and Canada. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==

* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

initial_version:
The '''[[Baptist Church]] in [[Ukraine]]''' is one of the oldest [[Protestant]] [[Christian]] denominations in the country.  

== History ==
The predecessors of todays Baptists, the [[Anabaptists]], were in Ukraine in the [[sixteenth century]].<ref name=risu>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/major.religions/baptists/ Baptists in RISU Portal]</ref>

The first Baptist [[baptism]] (or "baptism by faith" of adult people) in Ukraine took place in [[1864]] on the river [[Ingul]] in the Yelizavetgrad region (now [[Kirovohrad]] region), in a [[German]] settlement. In [[1867]], the first Baptist communities were organized in that area. From there, the denomination spread to the south of Ukraine and then to other regions as well. One of the first Baptist communities was registered in [[Kiev]] in [[1907]], and in [[1908]] the First All-[[Russia]]n Convention of Baptists was held there. The All-Russian Union of Baptists was established in the town of Yekaterinoslav (now [[Dnipropetrovsk]]).

After persecution in the 1920s, they were, to some extent, revived during and after [[World War II]]. In [[1944]], Baptists and Evangelical Christians united in the Church of Evangelical Christian Baptists (ECB). They were later joined by other smaller Baptist and Evangelical trends. At the end of the 1950s, 75% of the believers of the All-USSR Council of ECB lived in Ukraine.  Baptists in Ukraine experienced a revival in the 1970s, and are now among the most active Christian denominations in the country.<ref name=risu/>

== Membership and organization==
Baptists in Ukraine are organized and active in building churches and seminary education.  Nearly 90% of Baptists in Ukraine are united in the All-Ukraine Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists (AUU AEB), established in [[1994]] at the 22nd Convention of the ECB of Ukraine. Today, the union includes 3 [[seminary|seminaries]], 2 universities and 15 Bible colleges, and is estimated to have more than 300,000 members in more than 2,800 churches, with 3,160 clergy members.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90205.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007 - Ukraine]</ref> The union is engaged in publishing activity and has an extended mass media network. The AUU AEB is governed by a council composed of senior presbyters (bishops) of regional associations headed by the president of the council. In 1990—2006 the council was headed by Hryhorii Komendant. From May 2006 it has been headed by Viacheslav Nesteruk. The union closely cooperates with Ukrainian Baptists in the diaspora. The AUU AEB is a member of the [[European Baptist Federation]] and the [[Baptist World Alliance]].<ref name=risu/>  In addition, there are other associations of Baptists and Evangelical Christians, as well as individual communities and missions in Ukraine.

It is estimated that there are more Baptists in Ukraine than in all the [[CIS]] countries (including [[Russia]]) combined.<ref>Imogen Bell ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia''.  Taylor and Francis (2002) ISBN 1857431375</ref>

Baptists organized the first International Christian Theater Festival in [[Rivne]], which took place in July, 2007.<ref>[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;17018/ RISU Portal News]</ref>

== Persecution ==
During the 1920s, Evangelical Christians and Baptists were prohibited<ref name=risu/> in the [[Soviet Ukraine]].  Under the [[1996]] [[Constitution of Ukraine]], Ukrainians were given the right to free practice of religion.<ref>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96%2D%E2%F0 Official text of Constitution] — site of the parliament {{uk icon}}</ref>  However, as a minority and nontraditional religion the Baptists have been subject to persecution and discrimination, including being arrested<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/1999/209905.shtml Ukrainian Weekly ''Baptists detained as evangelistic meetings begin'' May 16, 1999]</ref>.  The Government of Ukraine facilitates the building of houses of worship, and Baptists have difficulties with the local authorities in Kyiv and other large cities while attempting to obtain land and building permits<ref name=usdos>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51588.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2005 - Ukraine]</ref>.   Baptist leaders have criticized the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] for continuing to publicly referring to Baptists with the pejorative Ukrainian word "sectanty" ("sectarians")<ref name=usdos/>, and about the activities of the group "Dialogue," which they and human rights groups characterized as a front for the UOC-MP that promoted hostility toward non-Orthodox Christians.<ref>[[USDOS]] [http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71415.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2006 - Ukraine]</ref>
  
== Korean Baptists ==
Beginning in [[1993]], the [[Korean]] [[Baptist Church]] has existed in Ukraine. As a religious organization, its focus is towards the [[Korean]] [[diaspora]] in Ukraine. Generally the preachers are Americans of Korean descent.<ref name=risu/>

== See also ==
* [[Protestants in Ukraine]]
* [[History of Christianity in Ukraine]]
* [[Religion in Ukraine]]
* [[Ukrainian Evangelical Baptist Convention of Canada]]
* [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]]
* [[Ukrainian Bible Society]]

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== Links ==
*[http://www.ecbua.info/ Official website of the Baptist Union] {{uk icon}}

[[Category:Christianity in Ukraine]]
[[Category:Religion in Ukraine]]
